points_of_difference.description: Measures the distinctiveness, personality, and unconventional nature of the branding. High scores indicate quirky illustrations, humor, or disruptive design systems.
high_score_indicators: Non-standard color palettes (e.g., Pink, Teal, Black)

points_of_difference.description: Extent to which the product positions itself as a health supplement or medical necessity through scientific claims and clean, clinical aesthetics.
high_score_indicators: Detailed nutrient lists on front (Calcium, Vitamins)

points_of_difference.description: Focus on sustainability, sourcing transparency, and environmental impact beyond standard organic certification.
high_score_indicators: Packaging sustainability claims (e.g., renewable plant-based cap)

points_of_difference.description: Perception of the product as a premium, artisanal ingredient suitable for coffee or culinary use, rather than a commodity staple.
high_score_indicators: Premium dark or gold color codes

points_of_difference.description: Emphasis on the raw ingredient, lack of processing, and farm-to-table connection through rustic visual codes.

points_of_parity.description: Presence of AB (Agriculture Biologique) or EU Leaf logo.
Explicit claim regarding absence of added sugars.
Claims highlighting French, European, or specific country of manufacture/oat origin.
Visual presence of the official Nutri-Score grading system (A-E).

pod_scores.reasoning: Standard corporate design, highly structured layout with safe F-pattern.
Heavy emphasis on nutrient claims and nutritional scores.
Planet-score A, renewable resource cap claims prominently displayed.
Mass-market finish, photorealistic but commercial illustration style.
Uses green/oat colors but feels industrial rather than rustic.

strategic_insights.title: The 'Barista' Bifurcation
strategic_insights.description: The category has split into two distinct visual worlds: 'Functional Breakfast' (Private Labels, Bjorg) utilizing medical/agricultural codes, and 'Lifestyle Coffee' (Oatly, Minor Figures, Califia) using bold, minimalist, and non-food aesthetic codes. This suggests different usage occasions (pouring on cereal vs. frothing for coffee) are driving design strategy.

strategic_insights.title: Eco-Scoring as the New Standard
strategic_insights.description: While 'Bio/Organic' is a Point-of-Parity (saturated market), 'Planet-Score' and 'Bio Équitable' are emerging as the new premium differentiators. Brands like Bjorg, La Mandorle, and Biocoop are leveraging these to signal superior ethics beyond simple ingredient purity.

strategic_insights.title: Visual Homogeneity in Private Labels
strategic_insights.description: Retailer brands (Carrefour, U Bio, Auchan, Casino) rely heavily on a generic 'Earth Tone' palette (Greens, Beiges, Browns) to signal organic. This creates a 'sea of sameness' on the shelf, making it difficult for consumers to distinguish between retailer offerings without reading the logo.

strategic_insights.title: The 'No Sugar' Baseline
strategic_insights.description: The 'No Added Sugar' claim has transitioned from a differentiator to a Point-of-Parity. Almost all analyzed functional brands highlight this. Brands not making this claim explicit (even if true) risk losing health-conscious consumers who now expect it as a default.

category_summary: The Oat Milk category is highly crowded and polarized between functional, earth-toned organic staples and bold, minimalist lifestyle brands targeting coffee culture. While organic certification and 'no sugar' claims have become baseline expectations, brands are now differentiating through specific 'Barista' performance claims or deeper ethical commitments like biodiversity and planet-scores.
